headline: Bake Sale Lemon Bars
description: They are very, very easy to make, and really fabulously delicious.
name: Bake Sale Lemon Bars

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease a 9x13 inch baking pan.
Combine the flour, 2/3 cup confectioners' sugar, and butter. Pat dough into prepared pan.

Bake for 20 minutes in the preheated oven, until slightly golden. While the crust is baking, whisk together eggs, white sugar, flour, and lemon juice until frothy. Pour this lemon mixture over the hot crust.
Return to the preheated oven for an additional 20 to 25 minutes, or until light golden brown. Cool on a wire rack. Dust the top with confectioners' sugar. Cut into squares.

review.reviewBody: Came out perfect!

These are by far the best lemon bars. I follow the recipe exactly, but I use a food processor for the crust and it comes out perfectly every time. Just put flour and confectioner's sugar in first, then the butter (straight from fridge, cut into chunks) and pulse until combined and the consistency of cornmeal. Don't process until it comes together. Dump the powdery crust mix into the prepared pan and press it into a crust, making sure it's even. Continue as written in the recipe.

Loved it! super easy and they taste amazing! I thought the crust would be too bland but it worked nicely with the lemon flavor. They take about an hour and look so nice, I would definitely consider them for a bake sale of sorts.

These are good as written, but 2 additions made them over the top. First, add 1 tsp vanilla to the crust. And second, add a few drops of lemon oil (found in the candy section of a specialty grocery store, NOT essential oil). Also, the temp written is perfect for a glass baking dish.
very good recipe I make these a few times a month and always use this recipe
Gourmetmommy modifications make this the best.
I'm a lemon bar junkie and these were entirely too sweet for my enjoyment and not nearly lemony enough. If you prefer very sweet, then this is the recipe to follow.
it was fun to make but the batter was really sticky and was sticking to my tools and so it was hard to spread into pan.

I love to bake. I use many different baking websites, but allrecipes is BY FAR my favorite, and I would like to say: this recipe is amazing! I couldn't wait for them to come out of the oven, so I tried some of the batter. It was DELICIOUS. I could not believe it. Later on 25 minutes later, I tried one and I said to my self. I am DEFINITELY making this again.
Easy and delicious!

perfect just as they are. I brought these to a cookie exchange so i made them a mini muffin pan for less mess. youâ€™ll need to make a bit more crust but there was plenty of filling. The crust is sooo simple yummy and flaky. i do enjoy sour and sweet so i might add a bit of rind next go around. lots of people trying to complicate this recipe in an effort to make it better but really its perfect as is.
Turned out fantastic. It was the first thing to disappear at the baby shower.
I made these for a bake sale and they were very good I almost didn't want to give them away! The lemon wasn't overly strong, just right!
It just needs more lemon juice in it, otherwise it is very easy to make and makes a very nice lemon bar
I would make sure that you oil/line the pan very well. There lemon bars can stick to your pan very well.

Didn't come out well at all. The lemon curd just didn't bake and as the dough it just wasn't turning into a dough so i had to cook it on low heat for a while. And it was too sweet. This was total fail for me.
Made this for my niece's baby shower and everyone loved them!
3/24/19 - Super easy. Super fast. Super Yummy!
I over baked it a little but I enjoyed it. The minimum time was too much but then again I have a very weird cooking oven so it might not have been the recipe's error but mine.

My household absolutely loved these bars. I used lemon juice from a lemon and added 1 tablespoon of grated lemon rind as suggested. I also put crust ingredients into pan while still crumbly not letting it get to a dough consistency. This makes it easier to spread. I used a metal spoon for that as the heat from my hand was melting the buttery crumbs. I will be making this for Christmas gathering. It is delicious!

I have gotten SO many compliments and requests for this recipe! 
I squeeze fresh lemons(not sure if that makes any difference or not). And I'm not sure if my oven temp is just off or what, but you might want to watch the baking times. I usually only do about 14 minutes for the crust and 17 mins for the final bake time. But even when I have over cooked them a bit, they are still super yum!!

People need to leave recipes alone. And then you whine about it. I made it EXACTLY the way it says. 
PERFECT. I love it and so did 3 other people.

Seems like some love this recipe and others think it's way too thin and sweet. Personally, I like my desserts sweet! Tried this and it turned out perfect the first time, very lemony but also nice and sweet. Thanks!
Iâ€™ve made many lemon bar recipes. This one, is by far my favorite. Itâ€™s very easy and quite delicious.
I made the recipe with the recommended changes in the comments. The flavor was okay, but they stuck horribly in the pan. I would not make these again.

The crust burned the first time. Threw it out and tried again decreasing the time. Baked the squares and they burnt and stuck to the pan. Checked other recipes on this site and no one bakes these at 375 degrees. Could that be my problem? Won't try a third time.

We have two shifts of full time care givers for my elderly mother. I like to make them special threats to show how much we appreciate everything they do for us. They both love lemon, and they really LOVE these lemon bars!. I read some of the "changes" to this recipe that are posted, but I don't think this recipes needs any changes The changes makes it very similar to a recipe that I saw posted by the Barefoot Contessa. I tried that recipe, too, but we like this one best.
I've made this for the past 15 years and it's the one thing everyone always asks me to make/bring. I use salted butter but keep everything else the same.
Such an awesome recipe!!!
Will make it again.
Will make it again.
Very easy to make. Made no changes to recipe. Too much crust and not enough lemon.

accidentally cooked on 350 (times worked well, i think it may have burned had i been on 375). the crust has way too much butter in it. was not lemony enough for me but it tasted good. 
not sure if i would make it again... would probably try to find a different recipe with more lemon in it

I followed the original recipe, but added a zest if 1 lemon to the crust.and thought the bars had a perfect flavor. If you do not like your deserts sour but want some lemon taste this is for you. I read lots of reviews for this recipe and some suggested to double the crust, I wouldn't do it. There is plenty of a crust in this bars, almost as much as filling (I made it in 15:9 pan) If you have a trouble to spread the crust, cover it with the piece of a plastic wrap and roll over with a small rolling pan or press it with your hands or spatula.
And I am not sure why some added a yellow food coloring, my lemon bars were very yellow without it. 
Also, when i make it again, I will reduce baking time of a filling by half. My oven overcooked it a bit.
Thank you for sharing the recipe
It was amazing! All of the flavors worked well with each other and created something that will go down in history as one of the most breathtaking desserts!!!!

These were easy and quick to make. I love stuff that's easy and tastes good. I baked for 25 mins, which was too long for my oven. They got quite brown on the bottom and edges. Next time I'll lessen cooking time.
I make these every year to go on my Christmas trays for family and friends. They get asked for every year.

Absolutely wonderful, but the crust seemed to take a lot longer than 20 mins to firm up and become golden brown.
I will definitely be making this again.
The base was very good but the top was not very lemony
I follow this recipe exactly and it is fantastic! My son asks for these every time he comes home.

I've been making these for years and I should've reviewed it sooner. I usually add a smidge more lemon juice. But, other than that, I keep it as it is. I am asked for these CONSTANTLY. When I make them for a party I often make a X6 batch and I never have leftovers. People will always pick up and extra few as they're leaving and even ask if they can take some for someone who's not there. Women I work with have asked me to make them for their parties and even asked for batches of them so that they could give them as gifts. They're delicious and people go crazy over them to an almost odd extent.
Excellent recipe for bake sale. They asked for more!
best lemon bars I have every had.

These are my family's and friends favorite. I have made them so many times I have lost count. I make double batches and they go fast that I may have to make 2 double batches! This is the only lemon bar I will ever make . King Arthur recipes are all I use for baking! Thanks for such wonderful recipes.
I made these for our bake sale...so delicious. Sold out quickly!
Sadly, they turned out rubbery and hard. Couldn't even taste the lemon.
Turns out every time.

I think I found a new favorite dessert. I followed the recipe exactly and they turned out great. They didn't need any changes. Since I'm a lover of key limes I think I may make them later and substitute key lime juice for lemon juice
These taste delicious, but I'm only giving 4 stars because it would be even better if the lemon curd was doubled.
My family loves this, so did my friends! Very easy to make.

Oven @ 350. Bake crust 14 min. If you should wish to increase the volume of filling: 6 room temp eggs, separate yolks kept to the side. Whip whites to soft peaks, set aside. Double the flour to 6 Tbsp, cream together with 1 & 3/4 c sugar, 1 full c of lemon juice (at least 4 very large lemons) and the 6 yolks. Add tsp lemon zest. Fold the whites into yolk mixture. Pour over warm crust. Bake 19 min. til set and just barely golden brown. Okay. But the original is better.

This recipe is very easy and the lemon bar came out beautifully! I received so many compliments for these - one person even said it's been 25 years since she's had a lemon square this good. 
I followed the original recipe - the only negative thing about the bars is they burned a bit on the top edge against the pan. When I make them again I may reduce the temp like some of the other reviews suggest.
I didn't make any adjustments to this recipe. It is the perfect balance between sweet and tart. Love it!
Delicious as is. Cooking times may vary depending on your oven though. My daughter made these for a bake sale on her college campus and the requests keep coming even after 3 years. They're fabulous!

So my sister and I decided to make this due to our extensive collection of lemons. We started off strong, but we messed up badly when we forgot to add the flour in the first part of the recipe. Then, we re-did it and then we burnt it. But the next step of the recipe went well until we put it in the oven for twenty minutes. It was puzzled us that it was still gooey after all that time, but it turns out that the oven was never on. I imagine, with the proper skills required in baking, this would a great treat to sell or serve. However, this disappointed our mother.
I followed the recipe exactly and we loved these. This is the first lemon bar that my whole family has liked (6kids, husband, myself).Definitely making these again. Thank you
I made these for a bake sale and I was sold out half way through! These taste amazing I just loved them. I am making it again for Christmas. Don't change the recipe its perfect the way it is!
My family just didn't like them very much.
This has been my go-to lemon bar recipe for years. I make it exactly as directed, and it's great. A good, classic lemon bar recipe.
Everything the same except add the zest of the lemon. Half in the crust and the other half in the filling. I get so many compliments whenever I make these
I loved them they were great AS THEY ARE in see no point in making a recipe if your only going to make your own at the end
This is the best lemon bar recipe I have ever tried. I'll never need another recipe! These are perfect! If you like a thicker layer of lemon, try doubling the filling. It turns out great.

After reading the comments, I hesitated to follow the recipe exactly so I added a 1/2 c lemon juice and zested a lemon, baked it in a 13x9 glass pan at 350. I added a little more flour. I felt the filling was plenty with 3 eggs. Just tart enough without being too sweet. I would make them again. I don't like altering recipes but in this case, I thought I had better try lowering the temp and adding more lemon juice. They turned out great.

1st of all, when life or friends hand me lemons, what do I do?? Make lemon bars of Course! 2nd of all these were FAB U LOUS! !! I made no changes food wise other then doubling the filling, adding the zest of three Meyer lemons and juicing them. I read to drop the temp to 350, I really think this was the Right call, if you cook those eggs too fast, you might get a rubbery texture and that was something I was Loathe to have hapoen. I did add some salt, just a pinch, to the crust n lemon. Also, not sure why all the fuss about the crust. I made it exactly and just pressed it in the pan. It wasn't sticky either, just crumbled fine. My pan was an aluminum one that was about 9-11 maybe, perfect bar size. So GLAD I doubled that filling too cuz there would have been basically more crust then filling, that would NOT have been good eats! I took the time to line that pan with foil and sprayed it with grapeseed oil. The bars slid right off the foil, no trouble. My hubby n DS really loved them too. Heck even the Dog liked em! Lol These are a keeper for sure! Thank Elaine!!

I have to admit that I have never enjoyed lemon bars, and would have never thought to seek out this recipe if I had a say in the matter, but sometimes to get ahead you just need to know to do what you are told and my brother never learned that lessons and we all know how well he is doing still looking for work in Kentucky. I guess Scott was right. If you are feeling bold, consider drizzling salted caramel over the tops of these bars and adding a hint of mint and lime to the mixture. Admittedly, it is a wide departure in taste, but I have found that variation is at least on par with the original recipe if not superior along another spectrum. I also find these burn easily if baked for longer than 90 minutes, even at lower temperature.
I accidentally used 1. Whole cup of butter for the crust but they still turned out wonderfully

Very good dessert, but I suggest using 1 1/2 tablespoons of zest instead of just 1 tablespoon, to add more of a lemon flavor. Also add 1/4 cup of water to the "crust" dough to make it easier to work with.
Delicious! add a little more lemon and you'll love it.

I found these to be very good. Made as is the first time. Wanted a bit more filling, so next time I added an extra 1/3 recipe of filling, baking it just a bit longer. Try the original recipe first THEN give it a 1 star or thumbs down if that is how you feel.
I really thought this recipe was delicious. I think it is the best I have ever made. I will show this recipe to my family and friends so they can taste how good they are too!

Growing up, I abhorred all things citrus dessert, but making these for a friend forced me to try them...after all, a cook shouldn't serve food they themselves have not yet tasted ;) these were delicioso!!!!!! ??

carrie i had no problems at all and i prepared for 150 servings
 the recipe says till golden brown if its burnt its has to deal with you not the recipe ive been a chef for 23 years things only burn if you let them and nuber 2 recipes are guidelines not rules you should try to make it yours

Make it for an actual bake sale. Everyone loved them. Made another batch and sent most of them into with husband to work. Got actual thank you emails from his co-workers!

And, I made them EXACTLY as the recipe says. They stayed crisp and were excellent. I like how sweet they are because I don't want to eat a bunch of these at one time. Just a small square satisfies.
excellent. Best if let to cool completely....and even better the next day. Thanks.

I melted the butter, added the dry ingredients, mixed well and then patted it into a 9X13 glass pan. Baked for 14 mins.
Used 2/3 c lemon juice, grated lemon rind of two lemons, 4 eggs and 1/4 c flour for the topping. The lemon rind gives lots of extra flavor.

I hate to do a bad review, but I'm not sure what happened. There was not enough lemon mixture for the top. Mine were not even close to as thick as the picture. Also the edge got really brown. I'm going to have to pass on this recipe again.
Love this recipe, only thing I added was 2 tablespoons of lemon and 2 tablespoons of lemon zest. These are really good and everyone enjoys them.

I've made this a few times now. Twice according to the recipe, and a few times with some alterations (include Gourmet Mommy). I actually find many aspects of this recipe fine as is but: 1) Definitely decrease the temperature of the oven to 350 and remove your crust at 10 minutes, remove the filling at 15-17. 2) I find the filling ratios (sugar to lemon) fine as is. I do think that the technique needs to be modified though because the bars are a little thin. Make sure to use room temperature eggs. Separate them and keep the yolks to the side. Whip the whites until they form soft peaks. Then cream together the flour, sugar, lemon juice and yolks. Fold the yolk mixture into the whites. This will help give some volume to the lemon part.
Made to reviews recommendations wished I would have used the orginal recipe.
Made these for a baby shower...they were gone as fast as we could put them out...fantastic!

This recipe is really simple and delicious. My family can't stop eating it. I love the tastes; sour, but sweet in the same time
i have to give BIG 5 STARS!

DOUBLE the ingredients for the crust. And for the rest of the recipe, DO what GOURMETMOMMY does-decrease temp to 350 degrees. Put in 9 x 13 enameled metal pan. Bake 15 min. For filling, double flour and eggs, use 1 C lemon juice and 1 3/4 C sugar. Bake 20 min. With these changes to the recipe, you will get delicious lemon bars! Do NOT use the original recipe!

Omit Food DYE!!!
these were excellent and soo easy to make!!!

This is four stars for the changes GOURMETMOMMY mentioned, since most reviewers tended to go with her suggestions. It wasn't bad, but it wasn't as amazing as I hoped they would be. Maybe it's because I only have whole wheat flour and I only used 1.5 cups of lemon juice (I ran out), and I didn't douse the top with tons of confectioners' sugar--I added a thin layer to it, which was absorbed by the filling part and did not end up looking like the picture; I'm just not sure. I think if I make it again, I shall use some actual lemons to get some pulp in there, and maybe not use whole wheat flour. Still good, just not perfect.
Very easy to make a lot of compliments, will make again.
I did not care for this recipe. The textute was rubbery. My husband didn't like it either and he is far from a fussy eater.
Made as is and they're tasty but 1) a little thin for my liking and 2) I would like them a bit more "lemony". Next time I'll use some alterations from other reviewers. The crust is fantastic though!!
Insane! Easy and too delicious. As soon as they cool, try one for yourself before everyone scarfs them down! The edges are the best :)
Where's the lemon? Should be called "sweet bars" not lemon bars. No one even knew they were lemon bars. SKIP this if you are looking for lemon flavor.
These are awesome! I reduced the sugar and increased the lemon. We like 'em a bit more twangy.

Yum, yum, yum. I doubled the crust, but did not double the lemon mixture. I used a 1/4 c. fresh squeezed lemon (I had a half left in the fridge) and 3/4 c. lemon juice. I added 3 drops of yellow food coloring. Made sure to keep track of the time, as to not burn the crust or lemon topping. Very good!!

I can't really rate this for the original recipe because I didn't make it yet but according to Gourmet Mommy's recipe, the bars were waaay too sour! I am about to make these with the original recipe but recommend lowering the temp to 350 and bake the crust at 12-15 minutes and then baking w/ filling for 20 minutes.
the slight changes made by GOURMETMOMMY made these perfect for our tastes. Thank you Elaine for a wonderful recipe to use as a base :)

The first time I made this,I did not like this at all! However I tried a second time using most helpful ratings and then it was great---there needs to be another recipe instead of this one written. 

I doubled the lemon mixture part except the white sugar. used 350 setting baked crust only 15mns, used 3/4cup of lemon juice and 1T of lemon extract in my crust mixture. I also added lavender to my lemon mixture after pouring it on the crust. I will make it this way again.

These were WONDERFUL! My husband and I made the recipe together tonight for fun. He has not baked before, but thought it was a very quick and easy recipe to make. We were both very excited about how they turned out! I followed the recipe given except I baked at 350. For this southerner, the bars were the perfect balance of sweet and tart!

This recipe didn't work for me, there was way too much crust, not enough lemon. The base was black after 10 minutes and it said to put it on for 20, then when i put it in again to cook the top it was just even more black, and it started making mountains in the top.

I have no idea what the rave is about but I think the crust was overdone and I even took it out early. second of all, aren't the bars supposed to be gooey? The recipe timing and temp is way off and they aren't even yellow. Sorry - this is a no go for me.

My whole family loves these, just a written. Well almost. Sometimes I make the full recipe, but put it in a 9x9 pan for thinker bars. I also adjust the cooking time a bit for my oven. And I have used key lime juice as well! Yummy!!
I rate this 5 stars using GOURMETMOMMY's recipe changes..
